awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Program in Molecular Biosciences at the University of Oregon
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to the University of Oregon (UO), in Eugene, OR, will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2018-2020. Student interns are trained in scientific research methodologies, presentation, critical thinking, and experimental design. The scientific focus of the program (UO REU) is in molecular biosciences. UO REU provides closely mentored cutting edge research projects in a rich active learning environment for interns. Research areas include molecular biology, biochemistry, structural biology & biophysics, bioinformatics, molecular neurobiology, molecular evolution, microbiology, developmental biology, genomics, molecular genetics, cell biology, and computational biology. The Program features training in professional and responsible conduct of research, graduate school counseling, training in oral and written scientific communication, accessing, processing, and evaluating scientific literature, and informal and formal presentation of research outcomes. Weekly research group discussions, professional development workshops, faculty seminars, and oral and written progress reports provide rigorous preparation for graduate school and careers in research. Professional and social interactions with active researchers at all levels are offered. Recruiting and selection strategies focus on students having limited access to research opportunities, students from groups underrepresented in STEM, disadvantaged students, and those with disabilities. The selection process involves all participating faculty. 

It is anticipated that a total of 30 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program. Students will learn how research is conducted, and all interns are expected to attend and present findings at national professional conferences. The program aims to enhance the diversity and talent of the next generation of life scientists in the research community and train role models for future generations

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure (Directorate for Biological Sciences) will be used to assess the effectiveness of the training program, and UO REU specific focus groups and assessment will be used as well. Students will be tracked after the program to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information is available by visiting http://uoreu.uoregon.edu or by email (uoreu@uoregon.edu) addessed to the PI, Dr. Peter O'Day, or co-PI, Dr. Bryan Rebar.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report NSF 1758015 (2018-2022) 

The REU Site program Molecular Biosciences at the University of Oregon for 2020-2021 met each of its program goals to the extent possible under COVID-19 pandemic related constraints. We were compelled to cancel the program for the summer of 2020, and we completed our final summer in 2021 with primarily virtual experiences. The program objectives included: elevating national competence in STEM fields; enhancing access to research careers for students who have had only limited access to research experiences; expanding participation of minority researchers in STEM careers; and providing training and guidance to graduate students and postdoctoral fellows so that they can develop key skills as effective mentors. The program successfully provided comprehensive and focused training so that interns would be better prepared for graduate education and research careers. In the process, graduate students and postdocs developed mentoring skills important for their careers in research and education. The success of the program also contributed to our diversity action strategy goals for UO graduate programs. The program interns advertised and elevated the reputations of our research programs nationwide and increased the network of students from under-represented groups considering research careers.

Goals of individual program interns included: gaining experience-based education in science research; developing research and academic core competencies; understanding strategic design, creative reasoning and experimental approaches; learning and developing methodological and technical skills; enhancing deductive and inductive reasoning skills; enhancing and practicing communication skills; boosting personal confidence by way of professional and social interactions with faculty, postdoctoral fellows, and graduate students; and gaining insights into and accessing graduate education and research environments. For most interns in summer 2021, in-person aspects of these goals were not addressed due to COVID-19 constraints.

In the funding cycle reported here, we trained interns recruited from groups traditionally underrepresented in the sciences, students with disabilities, and students from institutions offering only limited access to research opportunities. For mentors and near peer mentors, we provided training that boosted their productivity and enthusiasm for careers in research and education. For interns, we developed and provided a workshop series on professional development that included the following topics: the culture and enterprise of research science; ethical and responsible conduct of research; data management; maintaining lab notebook; critically reading and evaluating scientific literature; internet-based research tools; developing and writing scientific articles; creating and presenting formal scientific oral and poster presentations; diversity in science; career advising, negotiating graduate and professional schools; and accessing career opportunities in biosciences. We provided training in scientific communication to enhance skills in speaking and writing with precision and enthusiasm.

We used formative and summative approaches to assess and improve all aspects of the program. Both internal and external evaluations were done each year. Implementation evaluations and progress evaluations were made. We tracked the career progress of REU alumni to gauge the influence of their collective educational experiences on their career choices. Our tracking data can be used in longitudinal studies that would evaluate our program as well as REU Sites nationwide.

Results of our evaluations indicate that the program has provided valuable research experiences each year to all interns, effectively trained undergraduates in research methodologies and culture, enhanced their access to research careers, helped increase the diversity in life science fields of research, and effectively trained graduate students and postdoctoral fellows to become effective mentors. The program promoted awareness, confidence, and understanding through experience-based learning. Interns advanced discovery and understanding, and bench mentors gained experience and advice in teaching and training. It also contributed to national efforts to broaden STEM participation of students from under-represented groups. Most interns presented their findings at national conferences, providing key dissemination and enhancing science and technological understanding broadly. Mentors and faculty enhanced their skills by reviewing program and intern evaluations and effectively addressing challenges.
